image.altText: Three women speaking with news microphones in front of them.

items.synopsis: After former Melbourne school principal Malka Leifer was sentenced to 15 years in prison for sexually abusing two students in her care, one victim told reporters outside court of the "lifelong" effects of the offending.

title.children: Malka Leifer handed 15-year prison sentence for sexual abuse of 'very vulnerable' former students

image.altText: A densely crowded street

items.synopsis: A glimpse into the possible Australia of 2063 has been laid out in a major government report, which offers warnings as the country gets older, warmer and faces a more fragmented global order.

title.children: Major report lays out vision of older and warmer Australia in 2063

image.altText: Crash

items.synopsis: Russian authorities say Wagner's Yevgeny Prigozhin was on board a plane that crashed north of Moscow. Here is what you need to know.

title.children: Yevgeny Prigozhin listed among passengers, Wagner pays tribute to leader: What we know about the fatal plane crash

image.altText: Peter Dutton in the prime minister's courtyard

items.synopsis: The Australian Electoral Commission has said ticks would likely be counted as Yes votes, while a cross would likely not be counted, a decision that has attracted the ire of the federal Coalition.

title.children: 'Just stinks': Peter Dutton to complain to AEC about tick and cross Voice referendum voting

image.altText: dreamworld sign

items.synopsis: Ardent Leisure shareholders claimed the company misled investors about safety measures and corporate governance standards causing shares to trade at an artificially inflated price.

title.children: Dreamworld owner settles $26 million shareholder class action following ride that killed four

image.altText: Two men in suits smiling

items.synopsis: At the first Republican presidential debate of the 2024 campaign, Donald Trump was nowhere to be found. The frontrunner for the nomination was instead hosting a rival event on Twitter.

title.children: A Trump-less Republican debate went smoothly — until the host brought up 'the elephant not in the room'

image.altText: An aerial view shows the storage tanks for treated water and an opening onto an expanse of water.

items.synopsis: Japan has begun to discharge treated nuclear wastewater from the Fukushima power plant more than a decade after the disaster. Experts say the process is safe, but Pacific activists want the UN to intervene.

title.children: Japan releases treated wastewater from Fukushima nuclear plant

image.altText: Matildas players cheer reacting to a penalty shoot out in a large stadium

items.synopsis: Your kid is still wearing that Matildas merch and bugging you to join a local soccer club, but you're scared off by the reports of sky-high club fees. So, how expensive is it? And how can junior sport in general become more affordable?

title.children: So your kid wants to play soccer. Here's how much junior football and other sports cost per year

image.altText: People sitting in the common area around a fireplace

items.synopsis: Like Australia, New Zealand has been battling a housing supply problem. One group of friends came up with their own solution.

title.children: Six friends pooled their money for the home of their dreams. It almost wasn’t enough

image.altText: A 'stop here on red signal' road sign and orange cones with the Australian Traffic Management logo, with a car nearby.

items.synopsis: Hundreds of West Australian workers lose their jobs as one of the state's biggest traffic management companies is forced into liquidation.

title.children: Hundreds of workers sacked by text as WA contractor collapses, major road construction projects in limbo

image.altText: A Canadian smokejumper lays out his parachute.

items.synopsis: In Canada, thousands of firefighters from all over the world have united to battle the country's "worst fires in recorded history".

title.children: The Canadian men fighting the most remote fires without trucks and water tankers

image.altText: A mug shot of a murderer.

items.synopsis: Jean Eric Gassy, who was found guilty of murdering Margaret Tobin in Adelaide in 2002, loses his appeal to have his sentenced reduced from 30 years.

title.children: Deregistered psychiatrist who killed former SA mental health chief loses bid for less jail time

image.altText: A man and woman stand in a park with a dirt track and house behind them.

items.synopsis: Qantas has reported a mammoth $1.7 billion profit after years of COVID-induced turbulence, but once-loyal customers say the airline's recent actions put it at odds with its 'Spirit of Australia' motto.

title.children: 'You're not the airline that you used to be': Qantas customers left out-of-pocket despite bumper profit results

image.altText: Nina Kenndy and Katie Moon stand arm in arm with gold medals around their necks

items.synopsis: Australian pole vaulter Nina Kennedy soars to new heights, tying for the gold medal with American Katie Moon in a drama-charged final at the world athletics championships in Budapest.

title.children: 'Hey girl, wanna share this?': Nina Kennedy splits pole vault gold in thrilling world champs final

image.altText: Founder of Wagner private mercenary group Yevgeny Prigozhin in military gear.

items.synopsis: Ten people died after a private jet crashed in Russia's Tver region north of Moscow, Russia's TASS news agency reports.

title.children: Wagner boss Yevgeny Prigozhin killed in plane crash two months after mutiny, Russia's civil aviation authority says

image.altText: A lone woman in an orange high-vis vest walks through a burnt forest as blackened gums tower above her.

items.synopsis: East Gippsland and the north-west of Victoria are two regions facing an increased likelihood of significant bushfires during spring, according to the Australasian Fire Authorities Council.

title.children: East Gippsland on alert for spring fires as dark memories of Black Summer linger

image.altText: Two people, who cannot be identified, hold hands as they walk down an outdoor walkway.

items.synopsis: Christopher Moran says he fell prey to a notorious paedophile priest when he was a boy. Now an increasingly common legal tactic has robbed the 57-year-old, who has terminal cancer, of his wish to have his day in court.

title.children: After a lifetime of pain, Christopher's last hope for justice has been dashed

image.altText: A young man sitting on his desk.

items.synopsis: Police arrived to find a 58-year-old man dead inside an Arundel home yesterday. It is understood the deceased man was a stepfather to the councillor.

title.children: Gold Coast councillor Ryan Bayldon-Lumsden charged with murder of his stepfather

items.synopsis: The besieged abalone industry in south-west Victoria has been dealt another devastating blow, but divers have vowed to find a way forward.

title.children: Deadly herpes disease threatens abalone as authorities scramble to contain outbreak

image.altText: Multiple teenage boys crouch inside a cable car dangling at an angle above a forest.

items.synopsis: Children trapped in a cable car dangling from a broken zip-line believed they would never see their families again. Now Pakistan is celebrating a 15-hour-long rescue attempt.

title.children: New footage shows how teens in Pakistan survived marathon cable car ordeal

image.altText: A young blonde, white woman smiling in a clasroom

items.synopsis: The results from a brand new NAPLAN system show one in three students are not meeting minimum numeracy and literacy expectations. Experts say one solution lies with the teaching methods.

title.children: This school is defying the NAPLAN struggles at other schools. Here's how they did it

image.altText: A family standing outside a court house.

items.synopsis: The family an Indigenous teenager who died while in state care says recommendations of a coronial inquest into his death have not gone far enough.

title.children: Dead teenager's family calls for changes to child protection policy after inquest

image.altText: Rose Byrne with permed hair and a very high cut leotard stands in front of a pastel TV set

items.synopsis: The third and final season of Physical offers some less intense narratives about body image and disordered eating. But is the show still unhealthy for people to watch?

title.children: Physical tackles disordered eating head-on. But is it helpful or harmful?

image.altText: A white man in a suit and glasses stands at a podium in front of US flags and speaks and gestures with his hands

items.synopsis: Follow the day's events and insights as they happen with our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Qantas reveals results, NAB CEO says recession unlikely

image.altText: Henry Olonga at the SCG

items.synopsis: Retired cricketer Henry Olonga issues a warning about the pitfalls of social media, after he recently posted a heartfelt obituary for his old teammate Heath Streak, only to get a message back from Streak hours later.

title.children: Former Test cricketer's cautionary tale after prematurely declaring teammate's death

image.altText: Dark silhouette of a person wearing a hoodie.

items.synopsis: The children's identities were previously considered cold cases — some decades old — with not enough distinguishable clues in the online abuse material seized by authorities to identify them.

title.children: Facial recognition used to identify more than 300 probable child abuse victims

image.altText: Close up of interior of a mailbox containing inflated condoms, glow sticks, lubricants and fruit.

items.synopsis: When Doug went to talk to his neighbour about quotes for a new fence, he was expecting an amicable discussion. Instead, it was the start of a homophobic campaign of harassment.

title.children: 'No way we could stay': Gay couple forced to move over neighbour's homophobic abuse

image.altText: A young woman with curly hair sits on the ground propped up against a couch with a laptop on her lap.

items.synopsis: Drip pricing — the practice of incrementally disclosing unavoidable additional fees — seems like such an annoying trick that you may wonder why sellers do it. The answer is because it works, due to two fundamental cognitive biases.

title.children: The underhanded sales tactic we hate — but keep falling for

image.altText: A 14 year old girl sits on the ground.

items.synopsis: Elizabeth Russell was a teenager when she felt an unusual, severe pain. It would take 15 years before she knew what it was after being repeatedly dismissed by healthcare workers.

title.children: Why it took 15 years for Elizabeth's 'excruciating pain' to be diagnosed as endometriosis

image.altText: President Xi stands up in front of Chinese, South African, Brazilian and Russian flags.

items.synopsis: This year's BRICS summit has kicked off in Johannesburg, South Africa, where world leaders are expected to discuss adding new members to the group. What is BRICS and why do countries want to join?

title.children: 'Ongoing dissatisfaction': Expansion of the group called BRICS could mean a tilt in world power

image.altText: A pen of lambs in a saleyard in Bairnsdale.

items.synopsis: Consumers continue to pay high prices for meat while farmers say the prices they are getting are not worth sending their livestock to market.

title.children: 'Someone is making a dollar': Farmers shoot sheep rather than take them to market at a loss

image.altText: India moon lander's view of the moon from space.

items.synopsis: India becomes the first country to land near the Moon's south pole, just days after a Russian spacecraft crashed trying to reach the area.

title.children: 'Witnessing history': India celebrates being first to ever land on south pole of the Moon
